content: <articles>    <article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink/">   <front>     <article-meta>       <title-group>         <article-title>Air-Sea Gas Exchange at Hurricane  Wind Speeds</article-title>       </title-group>       <contrib-group>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Mischler</surname>             <given-names>Wolfgang</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics and Heidelberg Collaboratory for Image Processing, Heidelberg University, Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>J\ufffd\ufffdhne</surname>             <given-names>Bernd</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics and Heidelberg Collaboratory for Image Processing, Heidelberg University, Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Krall</surname>             <given-names>Kerstin E.</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, Heidelberg University, Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>       </contrib-group>       <pub-date pub-type="pub">         <year>2013</year>       </pub-date>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/11904"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="https://zenodo.org/record/11904/files/kerstin-krall-poster-sopran-2013-doi.pdf"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="https://zenodo.org/record/11904/files/kerstin-krall-poster-sopran-2013-doi.png?subformat=icon-90"/>     </article-meta>     <abstract><p>In a pilot study, air-sea gas transfer velocities of two different sparingly soluble tracers<br /> were measured in the unique high-speed wind-wave tank at Kyoto University, Japan. This<br /> tank is capable of producing hurricane strength wind speeds of up to 67 m/s. The<br /> measured transfer velocities spanned two orders of magnitude, lying between 11 cm/h and<br /> 1180 cm/h with the latter being the highest ever measured wind induced gas transfer<br /> velocity. They are more than a factor of 20 larger than the ones observed in the Aeolotron<br /> at the highest wind speed. The measured gas transfer velocities are in agreement with the<br /> only available dataset at hurricane wind speeds (McNeil &amp; D&rsquo;Asaro 2007). The<br /> disproportionately large increase of the transfer velocities found at highest wind speeds<br /> indicates a new regime of air-sea gas transfer, which is characterized by strong wave<br /> breaking, enhanced turbulence and bubble cloud entrainment. However, using only two<br /> tracers in the presented pilot experiment, the respective effects of enhanced turbulence<br /> due to breaking waves, additional surface and turbulence due to bubbles and spray as<br /> well as generally enlarged surface due to waves could not be separately quantified.</p></abstract>   </front>   <article-type>user-asi</article-type> </article>   </articles>
